moves.1... e5 2. f4 exf4 3. Bc4 Qh4+: !? A speculative move, not considered the strongest reply, leading to the type of tactics that appeal to KG players.
moves.5. d4 Bb6 6. Nf3: White has good development in compensation for the pawn and loss of right to castle.
moves.8. Qe2 Qh6: ?! Another Q move. White seems to have full compensation for the pawn which remains weak.
moves.9. Nc3 Ne7 10. Qe4 g5: ?! Determined to try and hold the pawn, but White is developing a strong attack.
moves.11. h4 Rg8 12. Rh2: Not just threatening the g pawn but preparing the R for action.
moves.12... Qg6: Black decides, belatedly, to give back the pawn but White retains a ferocious initiative even so.
moves.13. hxg5 Nf5 14. Bxf4 Nc6 15. Nd5: White has Black in a strong bind.
moves.16. c3 Nce7 17. Nf6: The White N settles on f6, and at this point is worth as much as Black's trapped rook.
moves.17... Rh8 18. Bd3 d6 19. Kf2 Ng8: Black wants to exchange Ns, but...
moves.20. Rah1: Here exd was to be considered, but White wanted to be cautious and strengthen the bind.
moves.24... Rxh7 25. Rxh7 Ba7 26. Ne5 Nxf6: Black is desperate to try and shake the bind, but it is too late.
moves.27. gxf6 Kg8 28. Rg7+: Here Black resigns. If...Kh8, it is mate. If... Kf8, then Bxf8+ Ke8 Rg8#.
